abstract: Create app intents and entities to integrate your app’s web browsing functionality with Siri and Apple Intelligence.
overview:
## Overview

To integrate your app’s web browsing functionality with Siri and Apple Intelligence, you use Swift macros that generate additional properties and add protocol conformance for your app intent, app entity, and app enumeration implementation that Apple Intelligence needs.

For example, if your app allows a person to open a website in a new tab, use the [doc://com.apple.AppIntents/documentation/AppIntents/AppIntent(schema:)] macro and provide the assistant schema that consists of the `.browser` domain and the [doc://com.apple.AppIntents/documentation/AppIntents/AssistantSchemas/BrowserIntent/createTab] schema:

To learn more about assistant schemas, see [doc://com.apple.AppIntents/documentation/AppIntents/Integrating-actions-with-siri-and-apple-intelligence]. For a list of available app intents in the `.browser` domain, see [doc://com.apple.AppIntents/documentation/AppIntents/AssistantSchemas/BrowserIntent].

### Make sure your entity meets requirements

If you use app entities to describe custom data types, annotate the app entity implementation with the [doc://com.apple.AppIntents/documentation/AppIntents/AppEntity(schema:)] macro. This makes sure Siri and Apple Intelligence can understand your data. For example, the intent in the previous section uses `TabEntity`. The following code snippet shows how the `TabEntity` implementation uses the [doc://com.apple.AppIntents/documentation/AppIntents/AppEntity(schema:)] macro:

The assistant schema for the `TabEntity` consists of the `.browser` domain and the [doc://com.apple.AppIntents/documentation/AppIntents/AssistantSchemas/BrowserEntity/tab] schema.

For a list of available app entity schemas in the `.browser` domain, see [doc://com.apple.AppIntents/documentation/AppIntents/AssistantSchemas/BrowserEntity].

### Make sure your enumeration meets requirements

To make sure Siri and Apple Intelligence understand custom static types for your intent parameters, annotate app enumerations with the [doc://com.apple.AppIntents/documentation/AppIntents/AppEnum(schema:)] macro. Then, pass the `.browser` domain and a schema to it. The following example uses the [doc://com.apple.AppIntents/documentation/AppIntents/AssistantSchemas/BrowserEnum/clearHistoryTimeFrame] schema:

For a list of available app enumeration schemas in the `.browser` domain, see [doc://com.apple.AppIntents/documentation/AppIntents/AssistantSchemas/BrowserEnum].

items.description: Assistant schema conformance for app intents that offer web browsing functionality.
items.name: AssistantSchemas.BrowserIntent

items.description: Assistant schema conformance for app entities that describe data for web browsing functionality.
items.name: AssistantSchemas.BrowserEntity

items.description: Assistant schema conformance for types you use for web browsing functionality.
items.name: AssistantSchemas.BrowserEnum

title: Making browser actions available to Siri and Apple Intelligence
